Package tage.rml

Interface Quaternion

All Superinterfaces:
Comparable<Quaternion>
All Known Implementing Classes:
Quaternionf
public interface Quaternion extends Comparable<Quaternion>
A quaternion represents an orientation about an axis in 3D space.

Quaternions have a scalar part, which correlates to an angle of rotation, and a vector part, which represents the axis of rotation. Note that the encoded scalar part is not encoded as an angle directly. This means that quaternion q = [w, v] = [w, v=(x, y, z)], where w is the scalar part and v is the vector part, is defined as follows: 

 w = cos(theta/2)
 v = [x * sin(theta/2), y * sin(theta/2), z * sin(theta/2)]
where theta is the actual angle of rotation around v, in radians. This means extraction of the w and v components is as follows: 

 theta = 2 * arccos(w)
 v     = [x / sin(theta/2), y / sin(theta/2), z / sin(theta/2)]
Author:
Raymond L. Rivera

    • conjugate

      Quaternion conjugate()
      Returns the conjugate of this quaternion as a new quaternion.

      The conjugate q' of a quaternion q = (w, [x, y, z]) is defined as: 

       q' = (w, [-x, -y, -z])
      Returns:
      A new quaternion that is the conjugate of this quaternion.

    • toMatrix3

      Matrix3 toMatrix3()
      Converts this quaternion to a pure rotation matrix.
      Returns:
      The orientation represented by this quaternion as a pure rotation matrix.

    • toMatrix4

      Matrix4 toMatrix4()
      Converts this quaternion to a matrix, representing a rotation with no translation.
      Returns:
      The orientation represented by this quaternion as a matrix with a rotation and no translation.

    • dot

      float dot(Quaternion o)
      Returns the scalar dot-product.

      The dot-product, also known as the inner product, will be a scalar value in the [-1, 1] range because it's the cosine of the angle between them, not the angle itself. In other words, for the scalar value to actually represent an angle, in radians, you must calculate the inverse cosine of it.

      Parameters:
      o - The instance used to calculate the dot-product.
      Returns:
      The scalar value of the dot-product.

    • normalize

      Quaternion normalize()
      Returns a new normalized instance from this instance.

      Returns:
      A new normalized (unit-length) instance with a length of 1.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - If the length of this instance is zero.
      See Also:
      • length()
      • lengthSquared()

      The length of this instance.

    • lengthSquared

      float lengthSquared()
      Returns the measured length of this instance without taking the square root.

      This method is provided for performance reasons. It avoids expensive square root operations for simple comparisons (e.g. sorting).

      Returns:
      The squared length of this instance.
      See Also:
      • length()

    • isZeroLength

      boolean isZeroLength()
      Determines whether this instance has a length of zero or not.

      Zero-length instances should avoid calling normalize(). Doing so will result in an attempt to divide by zero.

      Returns:
      True if this instance is zero-length. False otherwise.
      See Also:
      • length()
      • lengthSquared()

    • inverse

      Quaternion inverse()
      Returns a new instance that's the inverse of this, if possible.

      Checks to determine whether this can be successfully inverted. Inversion will not be possible if a division by zero takes place.

      Returns:
      The inverse of this instance.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - If this is non-invertible.

    • lerp

      Quaternion lerp(Quaternion end, float t)
      Performs linear interpolation from this to end by t, which is automatically clamped to the [0, 1] range.
      Parameters:
      end - The opposite end of the line along which interpolation will take place.
      t - The interpolation parameter.
      Returns:
      A new instance with the result.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the end is null.

    • slerp

      Quaternion slerp(Quaternion end, float t)
      Performs spherical linear interpolation from this to end by t, which is automatically clamped to the [0, 1] range.
      Parameters:
      end - The other end-point with which to interpolate along the arc.
      t - The interpolation parameter.
      Returns:
      A new instance with the result.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the end is null.

    • negate

      Quaternion negate()
      Returns a new instance that is the negation of this.

      Negation is the mathematical equivalent of: this * -1.0f.

      Returns:
      A new instance with the result of this negation.
